p: The reviewed studies investigated a large number of potential species’ responses to climate change (electronic supplementary material, table S2). These types of responses studied were not equally represented in the reviewed studies even when collapsing the initial 19 classes of responses into nine functional groups: the most commonly investigated climatic effects on species were changes in population size, changes in distribution and changes in phenology or survival. Few long-term studies described potential climatic effects on reproduction, disease prevalence, morphology or physiology ( table 4).
